OVHmvfAXCyJw11yzgXXpLA.text: A milk bar in Australia is our local corner store where you can buy milk, newspapers and the like. The Milk Bar is a lovely cosy coffee shop. A good place to hang-out, and relax, read the paper and enjoy a hot brew. I wasn't as impressed by the coffee as everyone else; I personally thought it was a little burnt/over-roasted, but perhaps that's just me. The vibe and decor are great; though perhaps the seats a little hard for extended sitting. Definitely worth a visit. The best coffee house I know in Soho.

MbM-h2RxCKIBnpTjSgY1mA.text: I'm a Canadian girl who got addicted to flat white's a few years back. I LOVED flat white on bateman but now Milk Bar has my heart. The guys know my drink and I'm not even there that much. The area is relaxed and chilled out. They are friendly, make good coffee and keep the place clean. I take EVERYONE who visits me here. I recommend it wholeheartedly!

R4DDx1KNvyQxzA6qI_3GXA.text: Great! I've been going to Milk Bar since their opening. Doing what Flat White couldn't do because of space and what others are only catching up on now. Scott, maybe the Barista 'ignored' you because he or she was busy extracting a coffee and concentrating on a product for another customer who was there before you? If you want fast service get a 'full bean' coffee at a McDonalds. Ignore that guy Milk Bar kids and keep texturizing and extracting!

UkzjhBtyqbAI2KeYjAOsfA.text: I visited this for the first time yesterday and loved it. It was about 10am and I wanted a little bit of piece of quiet and some breakfast. The day was grey and cold outside and 'Milk Bar' had a calm, welcoming vibe that is not often present in sister cafe 'Flat White' (Which is usually busy and a little cramped). Milk Bar is beautifully but subtely styled - like an old Aussie Milk Bar from the 50s complete with little wooden stools outside, multicoloured plastic door ribbons and dark wood flooring. I was recommended the scrambled eggs. Whilst they were being cooked I sat down at the back on one of the leather banquettes and just totally relaxed (rare for me), checked my emails and just felt right at home. My food arrived - perfectly cooked buttery scrambled eggs, grilled toast (lovely bread), some butter and an avocado. Everything was just totally spot on and made me miss Melbourne! Why is it Aussie and Kiwis know how to get food so right whilst we in the UK have no clue!? After my fantastic breakfast I ordered a strong flat white which was great. In general the coffee at both Flat White and Milk Bar is very good but not the best and I'm not sure on Monmouth for an espresso blend as their specialty is really filter coffee. However, it's good and light years ahead of most other cafes in town. Because the coffee didn't blow me away completely that's why Milk Bar only gets 4 stars but I'll go back again - there's more space than Flat White and I found the staff a little less loud!! In summary just the perfect place for a quiet early breakfast and reflection. Brilliant!

n0EurmGigyAyfLHXScdFjg.text: Good Music great people and great Gluten free food. I wish this place was by my work I would go every day :)

CVvMSwoTfE3XZHQA8hhUhg.text: Refurbished by 'new owners' at the beginning of August, the Milk Bar is effectively no more. Ill-designed, with huge overly bright lights hanging down over the tables, the menu obscured by new units, the walls a gharish colour, the food overpriced and unappealing. It looks like a bog standard cafe. The lovely laid back vibe has gone. the new owners huddle together behind the counter surveying their now empty tables.

SOIoe8CzVa6QbW2gZDDH8g.text: Sister establishment to Flat White on Berwick Street. It's like walking into a 1950s style coffee bar, with professionally made drinks and quality snackage. My one and only gripe is the music they play on the speakers; horrible Oz rock that makes your ears bleed. But if you're tone deaf, that shouldn't be a problem.

lSUd_3AVp-jNDUbcdmKWEA.text: Don't you love a place where you stipulate that what you mean by a long black is that it's an espresso shot on top of about an inch of hot water, and they say "that's how we do it." I don't care if they're not the friendliest bunch, I'm not without my coffee, either. Good milk texture in cappucino and flat white, and as per mentioned long black was excellent. What is it with the best coffee joints in London being Aus/Kiwi? Fab, I say.

RjJ1HHSBoVMd-M7-j5CASg.text: The coffee may be above average, but that doesn't make up for the appalling customer service I received when ordering a takeaway coffee on a Sunday afternoon. Despite an almost empty café, the barista ignored me for almost a minute when I arrived. His attitude was so sullen, it made me feel my very presence was a personal insult to him. There are far too many options for good coffee in Soho to put up with this sort of attitude. So long, Milk Bar.

nE4spJVomP6Nq5mWlKbTlQ.text: Probably the best coffee shop in London. The food is tasty, the music off-kilter (in a great way), and the coffee is fantastic. As a transplanted kiwi, Milk bar rekindles a longing for the wind-swept majesty of Wellington.The only downside is the price, especially for coffee. That said, you get what you pay for, the best latte around.

DPRfftMt6EYGllQc65awCg.text: This place is fantastic. The coffee is the best ever. I love this place so much. Just went in again today and chill there for a bit even thought it's raining today but there is nothing could stop me going to milk bar for a cup of flat white.

srsNxv3N9esjHgDurTsPQA.text: Sister coffee shop to Flat White just a couple of streets away. Just like flat White it has a great reputation and when I've been it has always been busy. Their latte art is second to none and the staff are always friendly and welcoming. It seems to have more of a bohemian clientele than flat White.

3jXAuo0JIvENP68u0Cp4kQ.text: THis place does one of the best soy hot chocolates in London. And the coffee is great. I only started drinking coffee this year because of a flat white I had here. Bloody delish. I feel like standing outside Pret in the mornings and shooing people a little further down the street. Maybe some fly posting needs to be done. I've started buying their beans too.

G5_P1-JC9gCAiiEnivcuNg.text: The coffee here can be pretty much perfect, but there is quite a bit of variation depending on who the barista is. One guy in particular makes very average coffee. Shame.

SufaYDM1QAgTjQOseH6Nhg.text: The sister store to Berwick Street Flat White, this shares all of the same attributes - great music, friendly staff and FANTASTIC coffee! It's slightly off the beaten track location, combined with its ample seating makes it slightly more comfortable to 'hang out' in than the more compact Flat White. Well with the search - and they do milkshakes too!

sndJqrImi5rYhZmL_dsRxg.text: Milk Bar is the newest coffee shop opened by the Flat White guys. The coffee is of a similar extremely high quality, and the staff, mostly Kiwis, are friendly as ever. There's a good amount of seating space inside, and most of the front opens up, which keeps it nice and cool when the weather's hot. Highly recommended!

kksO0lK80TaWWg7rEu0gYQ.text: Having lived in Sydney for 4 years I am always on the look out for a proper latte and this place has them. It's a bit pricey and the music is a bit loud but I still go there just for the coffee. The muffins are pretty tasty too

_wtQ8R-mzLXYKgC4IYruiw.text: great to sit down and people watch over a latte!!!!!

xhniFd7uGTkixBifPRNcog.text: Lovely place to sit and chill -- good rock'n'roll photos on the walls when I went and the coffee is wonderful. Limited food but done well. Ditch Starbucks, Pret and Nero and check it out!

Dp2iEUBvRPS79y3JhEonsw.text: Decided to supplement breakfast last Saturday with a professionally brewed coffee and wasn't disappointed by the Milk Bar. Far more relaxed than its older but more boystrous sibling Flat White and somehow seemingly more spacious. All I ordered was a flat white and it was perhaps the prettiest I've been served to date. Satiated the people-spotter in me too.

photos.caption: Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom. perhaps the prettiest latte art to date

igkhZcm9HjLW9ZDO7FNDwQ.text: I just got back from lunch there today and was overall very impressed. They don't have a huge variety of food with today's offerings limited to a number of sandwiches and stuffed croissants, ranging between £3.5-£5. A toasted vegetarian sandwich with some brie/pumpkin and sweet chilli sauce went down a treat with a creamy flat white coffee. Like their sister restaurant, Milk Bar has a couple of benches outside and with their wide awning makes it easy to sit outside, regardless of the rain beating down (though the wind might get you). Inside they have about ten or twelve tables in a dark, modern and sparse interior only decorated with a handful of small hangings. The attendants were warm and courteous, telling us what they served and patient as we made up our minds. Most importantly, the coffee was extremely well made with the decorative leaf pattern drawn into the top with the rest of the creamy foam. A flat white sitting down costs £2.50 and they have different sizes with difference prices if you decide to have it to go. I wonder how busy this places gets in the morning as I'm not confident they'd be much standing space for ordering and picking up coffees. Highly recommended for a great place and a decent coffee.

photos.caption: Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom. Leafy flat white coffee
Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom. Toasted sandwich
Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom. Inside Milk Bar

Q2H2r4wvEyudJR1tlBtHFQ.text: One thing I would like to make clear right away  Milk Bar's coffee is superb. I find the clean very pleasant and appealing. The staff is really welcoming and they put a lot of effort in pleasing the clients. And keep in mind that Milk Bar and Flat White are pretty much one and the same so don't forget about the loyalty card you can acquire if you frequently visit them as stamps are provided at both locations.

X6KiVCJvZwhPXQ9TugdRJg.text: Love antipodean coffee but hate hipsters?  Forget Flat White and try Milk Bar instead.Mmm... this place serves up strong and good coffee with ironic fashion choices and stupid haircuts kept to a minimum.  Its side-street location in Soho means it's not an obvious choice for passersby and therefore has more space to spread out inside.  Don't tell too many people about it, though, because it would be a travesty if those of a  paedophilic-moustache persuasion moved in.

Y3_A0gX1WO9LQECtIyH_oQ.text: Sweet! This place is like is the sister location to Flat White and with the lack of "nobber jons" that hang around this place gains a star. Still no loo but when I question the fella behind the counter about this he was so jovial about it that i seemed to forget my urgency to pee. That in itself is an achievement!So for the coffee again no filter, just an espresso watered down but maybe I was just in a better mood because it was quite tasty. Still not a touch on Monment but a good effort.

bPnZuO1auu-F8NLvO4In9A.text: Having a flat white at Milk Bar is a nice experience. Not only is it a uniquely Australian drink, but it looks pristine before you drink it and tastes great on the way down.The only criticism I have is that the music seems a little bit too loud for such a small space. Other than that, reasonable prices, friendly service and a nice coffee shop atmosphere.

hMp-ik1BqXvnUDUfcBjSiw.text: First there was flat white, then there was............Milk bar. Thankfully this coffee bar isn't trying to replicate our friends at Starbucks etc by giving you a huge cup of water and milk with a hint of coffee. They are spreading the word of of coffee greatness with their flagship drink THE FLAT WHITE!!!!I'll admit when i first discovered this place i was struck with a small sense of xenophobia " Aussies and new zealanders teaching me about coffee???? giving it their own fancy names??? Related to criminals the lot of them...ohhhh that tastes goooodddd" and so i was converted.Right in the centre of Soho with so many of my other favourite places around its a perfect rest stop when on a jaunt in town. As Lizzie G mentioned it also lacks the odious media types talking loudly about their NEXT BIG DEAL!!!  that so often frequent Flat white.Plus i get to pretend that im in a clockwork orange without even a hint of ultra violence (im a pacifist you see but do love a good read)It is a tad expensive (£2.50 for a relatively small cup) but when the results are so good im willing to concede that in this place at least you get what you pay for.

r3qIzfSrgw2ij2K0rJ0e7Q.text: I am a regular at Milk bar from the Great Latte and wonderful Gluten Free  food options and thats always a plus for me.I think the staff is really friendly.all and all a very nice experience.This is the place for strong and good coffee.

W_Gi96TPO5CUbMdxtLGGyA.text: Last Saturday I was here with a friend for a meeting. We got a good table and had some really delicious coffee and some muffins for breakfast.

TjNBCBgODE0q-_5dzKXgbQ.text: Three cheers for Milk Bar!  Lovely espresso beverages and yummy breakfast options make it a great addition to the Soho coffee scene.  It's also much more spacious than its Berwick St. sister, Flat White, making it a more comfortable place to hang out with your mates or get a little work done when you're on the road in London.My Flattie was smooth and delicious, expertly brewed by my friendly Antipodean barista (though to be honest I can't tell the difference between a Flat White and a latte).  My eggs and toast were perfectly prepared, and I was able to enjoy a productive hour or so working thanks to the free wi-fi I was able to tap into.On all fronts (coffee, food, experience) Milk Bar delivers.  I'll be a regular when in London.

dO0367Ix3lXU2RnVoTiFwQ.text: I am loving the fact that they put mini marshmallows in the hot chocolate. Especially because I had no idea that they melt and go all gooey (in the best way) and you can drink it. Man, just thinking about the potential fun times I've missed as a child, is bumming me out a bit.Anyway! I love this place, it's cute, there's always a uber cool and laid back person serving you here, they do things like recommend things and smile and seem a bit more interested than most in serving you. People are chilled out and mmmm, did I mention the marshmallows? Man, they are yummy.

rSleESuOkA8OR0UAX7xAjg.text: The guys over at Flat White calls this sister store the "cooler younger brother," and I think that's quite an appropriate comparison. More spacious than Flate White, it's also laiden with dark wood, which gives it a more subdued and relaxed atmosphere... athough loud music seems to be a shared trait between the two places.The mocha I had was perfectly thick, chocolatey and bitter --  one of the better if not best ones I've had here. The staff seemed to be well acquaitned with many that stepped in, and were also very nice to strangers like me. I like, I like. I'd definitely come here again and again, and to try out all the little treats and bites they have on the menu.

6aOmYg6c8LwnMacDXGsSRw.text: Thought I should do a review having virtually done one as a comment on Tristans very negative review. I spend a lot of time in Melbourne & miss my coffee when back in England. It's great to be able to get fantastic coffee in a few places in London  most of which appear to be Aussie owned or runMilk Bar was recommended by a Spanish waiter to whom I would say " Muchas Gracias !" coffee was awesome, staff were friendly . Loved it.Please open in Birmingham

sdJr_6nDrknofANLZgWDzQ.text: I was first attracted to this place because of its name. Milkbar, it's cute and has a nice ring to it. It's located in this deserted-looking street, and it's seriously a hole-in-the-wall. The decoration inside is quite pleasant, comparable to those hipster cafes in San Francisco I'm used to. If only it offered free wifi for its customers, this place would be an amazing place to do some revision for uni students. Additionally, the way their food was laid out was not very appetizing. Nothing looked fresh and inviting, and their service was "meh" also. I got their iced chocolate (which i assumed was what frozen hot chocolate in serendipity3 in NY is... i still don't know if they're the same thing) in a to-go cup, which was pretty good. I would definitely come back to try the real food, though. By that I mean their scrambles and sandwiches. Also, I will definitely make sure to check out their sister cafe Flat White down the road.

0qhKykmjXRHTuqnZlhkT0A.text: Great Breakfast!I had baked beans on toast (could have done with seasoning)Wife had French toast and the best coffee she had in London.One suggestion - would be nice to be able to order a second coffee from your table rather than having to get up and re-que, especially if you're halfway through your breakfast.

eW9BqPfGOgVU5VyruyYSVg.text: Due to a dairy-free promise for Lent, I've been sampling soy milk lattes across the city & had high hopes for Milk Bar.The price was a little steep (2.30 + 50p soya tax, for just a tiny takeaway cup?) and the staff were lovely (even matching in their hip checkered shirts) but... What kind of soy milk are they using? The latte was smooth & silky yet the taste was rather nasty, a little woody & with a bitter aftertaste. I will return after Easter to try one with real milk before I cast my final judgment, but in the meantime, I'm rather disappointed.

5jBhNtt3z2XC1h-yZh71pQ.text: as a huge fan of their sister cafe, Flat White, i was curious to see how Milk Bar would stack up. ladies and gentlemen: it is rad.the staff is super friendly and chill. i want them all as my friends. the 'kitchen' is super good too. i went for brunch and had the french toast with carmelized bananas, which  were - get this - VEGAN. ***disclaimer: I AM NOT VEGAN. i was a chef and am a avid meat eater. alot of my friends are various ways of veggie, so ive had alot of vegetarian and vegan meals- alot of them not really tasting much like actual food. THIS WAS REALLY GOOD. like i was complely miffed as to how it was made. they used some kind of tofu, bannan puree and molasas thing instead of egg and i was totally blown away. the Chef, Tim was really helpful in explaining it all for me. they also have these awesome sweet bar/biscuit things that are yum. music is random but generally great. even on a hot day, the fans really keep it nice and cool.one sad thing: they only stamp their loyalty card if you get coffee, which i dont drink. its a reason to keep going to Flat White, where they accept it for both.

ZwfNfOMlAiWnQIduMBGKlQ.text: "MILK BAR' is the place to go for a great coffee, adorable little cup cakes (or a bigger slice of something yummy if you're me), served with a smile. They also do great sandwiches - but I usually opt for something sweet with my coffee Once discovered you will be hooked. It's small but they do get to put some seating outside in the warmer weather to cater for their many fans, Interesting art on the wall, and mags to pore over are also a drawcard.

bFleQw6Z2uTT0fI6my_UVw.text: I stopped by the Milk Bar last week on route to a meeting for which I needed to do some last minute prep for. It was around 10am and I was desperate to escape the hustle of Soho and this place had a lovely welcoming tone.The Milk Bar is set out in a great way and the decor is subtle but effective - it is reminiscent of old  Milk Bar from the 1950's with wooden stools and dark flooring.I had a coffee and some scrambled eggs on toast which was delicious and I could get on with my work in a calm and pleasant atmosphere. The coffee was actually one of the best I have ever tasted. The staff are friendly but they could see I was working so they weren't too over bearing.The perfect place for a quiet early breakfast. Lovely!

tJ5mrFH3jPG6eOJhVtDyIw.text: Previously known as 'The Blue Room' a friendly coffee shop, home to the eccletic Soho crowd.Now known as Milk Bar...not as cosy as the 'Blue Room' but definitely better coffee...some of the best I've had in London. Friendly Kiwi barristas too.Highly recommended.

u9xkc0h5FU16cC1jbmX3cQ.text: Another cute and hipster-esque coffee shops in London. We went there for a quick coffee fix, and indeed it was quick. Our flat whites and soy latte got us started on our Sunday. The servers were friendly to the point where we were discussing about punctuation (is it goat cheese or goats cheese or goat's cheese?). Sadly, no wifi.

ZpCOIyCW_IOkTVsuIHMOIg.text: UPDATE (Apr 2014): NO MORE VEGAN BAKED GOODS. They do have gluten free options though. They no longer have their drink set menu, but the coffee is still strong and affordable.The fresh mint tea is a bit disappointing. If I were in Soho and needed a little breakfast, I would certainly come here for their avocado on toast meal! Lots of savoury things that sound nice on the menu.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------From (11/06/2013):Brownies, muffins and other goodies that happen to be vegan just hanging out with my affordable long blacks? Sign me up!Love the set prices of coffee and teas, which is less expensive than their sister Flat White down the road. They also used the much coveted Bonsoy as their dairy-free milk.See you soon Milk Bar!

lN_MvZgYiHNFiiWwR0v2CA.text: London is absolutely brimming with American-style coffee and tea shops.  While some are good and others less-so, Milk Bar is a truly great coffee shop in one of my favourite parts of town.While seating is VERY limited and lighting a bit lacking (look elsewhere if you're coming to read), Milk Bar provides customers with prompt and friendly service.  The lattes and cappuccinos surrounding with absolutely beautiful, and my chocolate milkshake was among the best I've had in the city.  Unless you're seeking out a quiet place to read or to bring a large group of friends, Milk Bar is worth a look.

RlfXhAM9HuLUaGBR01qUKA.text: Decent coffee; it seems like Milk Bar and Flat White enjoy the more acidic aspect of coffee. The decor is also really lovely.  However, I felt like I was being judged by the other customers... lots of hipsters. Kind of scared me.

dQBhofu__q4VGjfA0eY6fw.text: I stayed in london for two weeks in soho and definitely needed my coffee fix. I'm not usually a drip coffee person, even though I'm a yank, so I love a good shot of bitter espresso. Milkbar was my go to place for great coffee, and they also have a great cold brew! The breakfast is good too, eggs on toast, etc. Good coffee is essential for me, and milkbar did not disappoint.

Zaoz5NwARUxDJM915jghyg.text: We escaped from the rain here and sipped warm beverages while waiting for nearby Barrafina to open for lunch. My companions enjoyed their coffees and I quite liked my hot chocolate.We didn't stay long but when next I find myself in Soho I think I just might!

A7MTUJ2iv2HdYQdYQU_mWg.text: I'm not going to lie - there's probably not much more I can add, but I really wanted to give these guys a high rating to boost those averages!This is a cafe I'm really content to spend some time in lingering over my long black. It's the only place in London that - despite many repeated visits in other locations - have adopted me as one of their regulars and are happy to chat away to me. All thanks to that friendly New Zealand attitude no doubt.Bonus points go for the simple, fresh, veggie-friendly food. The homemade baked beans on toast were delicious, nutritious and light. Finally, they quite literally have water 'on tap' for you to guzzle and offset that caffeine buzz.I love the changing art work that they have on the walls, which always seems selected to suit my taste (bordering on the gothic). The music they play also always chirps me up (as if the smoothly blended caffeine didn't already). Any place that belts out Jimmy Eat World at 8am on a wet Tuesday morning is a winner in my book.

_MuyRBrnEiNhT4xAI9J99g.text: Milkbar gets a C, with 'could do better' as the comment.The decor is interesting and can spark conversation, and is typical of most of the gourmet coffee places in the area. The coffee is very good, but the service leaves a lot to be desired.For example, I was in there holding a can of coke (I'd gone in for a coffee), but they told me I couldn't come in there with the coke. They don't even sell coke. So I put it on the table and they said I couldn't leave it there. I had to either finish it up (i.e. down the can) or just throw it away. This was quite annoying. It also takes a while before they acknowledge your presence, dropping it a further star down the rankings.I still regularly go there for coffee though, because it's close to Chipotle.

98Pjcg4NQ2vJ9Uf30EPd-g.text: Cozy indie vibe, wifi, pleasant service, and a delicious eggs, bacon, and avocado breakfast. Wasn't serving cold brew or filtered coffee on the Saturday we came though, and the espresso I got as substitution was so sour as to be undrinkable.

7uwcXz8RCuOxLbsEKDnxlw.text: Oh man, if you are a weird ass loner with no friends in London like I am then milk bar is your shit (that sounds kind of gross... I meant it in a good way).I rolled in on a Saturday, orders a flat white an a plate of baked beans, grabbed a little table for myself and read for a bit while I waited for the deliciousness to start.  Guess what?  Over half the people in there were also there alone.  Nice. I loved the flat white.  Was it better than at flatwhite?  I don't know, just go to both and stop worrying about the comparison. Beans and toast?  I'm not gonna lie, that sounds like a stupid thing to eat.  You are telling me that you are going to mix together baked beans and toasted bread and feed me that?  You must be an idiot.  But no.   I get it now.  The beans and toast at milk bar were SO good.  I love you Milk Bar.  I see people claim its kind of expensive here, but I don't care about that, money can't buy friends so might as well spend it on little tasties like milk bar.

09Nu2BFuzLEK55bXqrvhag.text: Very much enjoyed a flat white at Milk Bar. This is definitely one of the best coffee shops that I have been to in London! Highly recommended! You might also want to try out their other shop, which is usually a bit more crowded.

photos.caption: Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom

2JNxmmxnUJEcEne3rassYg.text: This was probably my favorite of any food/drink establishment I found in London during my recent one-week stay in the city.  I stayed in a flat directly across from Milkbar and found myself going there as often as I could for coffee and breakfast.  The prices are a bit high when you think in American dollars, but everything I purchased was well-worth the cost.Knowing that I didn't want to resort to Starbucks or other chains while on vacation, I prepared for London by googling a list of the best coffee shops.  Milkbar was #3.  All I can say is that #1 and #2 must be out-of-this-universe fantastic because I can't really imagine anything much better than Milkbar.  The coffee is perfect.  Neither bland nor too bitter.  And on chilly, wet London mornings, it made me feel warm and cozy and calmy satisfied. The flat white was my favorite, and each time I had one I was more and more impressed by how good it was.  After living in Italy, I'm generally picky about my coffee, but Milkbar was just as good, if not better, than the finest espressos I had in Italy.The food is also delicious.  The scrambled eggs came out looking much more liquidy than what we see in America, but man were they delicious.  Creamy and rich.  And the bread used for toast was superb.  I also tried the french toast and although this sounds wildly dramatic, I could have died happy after eating it.  The best part was for sure the caramelized bananas - incredible!Moreover, the general atmosphere of the place was really comfortable.  They played good music (as a NJ native, I was surprised and excited to hear a Springsteen album one day), had interesting decorations and books, and seemed to attract a very relaxed, calm crowd.  The baristas were really nice and friendly.  When I told one girl how good the coffee was - better than anything I'd found in NY - she wrote me a list of coffee shops (several owned/managed by her friends) in New York!  Thank you Milkbar for being awesome and for turning my chilly London mornings into warm, fond memories.  :)

EGKYJxrL03dMEbypuE3ZDQ.text: Love London but let's face it - not known for it's good coffee! We were visiting for a week and after listening to my complaining a colleague told me about the Milk Bar. Wandered a bit until we finally found it but it was well worth the search! Cute and welcoming the coffee was terrific and made to order. For a coffee snob like me it was a real find. The folks that served us couldn't have been more helpful or accommodating. Between the personal connection and the great coffee it was a perfect way to start the day. Definitely on my places to visit again next time I'm in London!

DrzgmbQf-jubCyUsWeRwuA.text: I came to London for three days traveling alone.  I had heard about Milk Bar and that it had a good breakfast for relatively cheap (by London standards).I headed there on a Saturday morning prior to starting my 20 mile walk around London.  I loaded up on some scrambled eggs and avocado slices.  The eggs were cooked very good, not runny yet not too dry.  Eggs and avocado just go so well together and was good fuel for my walking.The place is very small inside so if its busy you might not get yourself a seat.  On this day there weren't too many people inside and it was quiet.As others have said, the lighting is very dim.  The service was competent.Not your typical hipster cafe, but definitely worth coming for a good light breakfast in SoHo.

3rimwnKAF0X9UDCcEYqj4g.text: Tucked away from the tourists plodding up and down Charing Cross, this little cafe was frequented by what seemed to be artsy fartsy yuppie hipsters, aka, the people I'm used to seeing at cafes, just chillin' on the sidewalk in front, which is happily devoid of traffic or bustle.  In other words, there exists a little coffee bubble here, and it's nice.  The flat white I ordered was good, if at the high end of the price point.  The service was friendly and good natured too.  The barrista was quite happy to debate the definition of flapjack, and how it properly represented the wierd oatbar behind the counter and how it could never mean pancake, and she'd fight me outside if she had to.  I turned down this proposition, happy instead to sip my flat white in the little soho bubble.

1rhnvKzj9YiVY402zhKM3w.text: As I recall Milk Bar is owned by the same great Aussies that brought us Flat White, the original or so I've heard.  So when I went in here I had high expectations.  All confirmed.  This place made perfect espresso too.  It also seemed to be a little quieter, roomier, and easier to get a table.  Also the baristas were cuter.  I really liked the artwork on the walls too.  What can I say this is as good as it gets people!  The center of espresso in the GMT timezone!!

eCiNXTJzqopXnHoCl2J57A.text: This place is one of the pioneering cafes in London's quality coffee scene. It is owned by the same people as Flat White, and has really lived up to expectations since opening earlier this year.The baristas all know exactly what they are doing. I had a latte, which had perfectly steamed, consistent milk. The coffee they use is there own unique blend, created for them by the Square Mile roastery. I have to say, it is one of the most well balanced, smooth espresso blends I have had for a while.As well as amazing coffee, there is a food menu of sandwiches, mini pizzas and various other things including breakfast.The interior is quite dark but in a really nice way, and attention is definitely paid to every little detail. Its location is perfect, just set back from the hustle and bustle of the main roads.It kind of reminds me of my favourite café in New York. I very highly recommend this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom

12onis9KJJlkobfTLrCtmA.text: Really a nice place, located in Soho. Not as light and woody-pure as Kaffeine - but that's a matter of style and personal preference. The bread is not as good as at Lantana, but still it tastes good. Milkbar is definitely a great place to stop for a coffee and a snack!

18JxDXiYe1H72qiSSrzGRw.text: BAM!That's what the coffee did to my face this morning. The body was soon to follow. None of this pansy assed murky acidic goo that has been served to me upon ordering coffee. (p.s. That's like telling a child they're going to Disneyland, and then taking them to a burned down warehouse instead.) Nothing like a healthy dose of disappointment to make you appreciate amazing coffee served up by the fine folks at Milk Bar. The atmosphere of this coffee house instantly put me at ease, inhaling Seattle's attention to brilliant espresso, exhaling Portland's low key charm. While not the absolute best Americano I've had here in London, on the yardstick of deliciousness, it's about eleventy billion above bog standard. Certainly a lovely place to meet a friend, a business partner, or simply sit and enjoy the sounds of people who can pull genius of out of a roasted bean.

buihw3hB_J6xITKb8ueiLg.text: With Australia and New Zealand leading the way in independent coffee these days, this is a good example of getting it right from your flat white to your latte. But the best, with summer almost here, is the ice coffee! A good strong exspresso with not crushed ice but a dollop of real ice cream. Fan- bloody-tastic! You could also try Flat White (MilkBars big sister) on Berrick St but I personally think FW doesn't have the charm of MilkBar.

eRLUAhydG2NPjzsviw6ZMg.text: I had a giant nosebleed walking into this place, and after it stopped was left with a ton of bloody tissues. No trash cans anywhere - but somehow the nice worker behind the counter was willing to touch them and throw it away for me (without asking??) I felt so bad. Anyway.. The coffee was good haha. and the food was great as well. They have an assortment of sandwiches and bread to choose from. My mother got toast and it came out in a heart shape with several spreads! (Jam, PB) Super cute. Everything was quite affordable and I was impressed by the quality of service.

photos.caption: Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom. Croissant
Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom. Toast + Avacado
Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom. Toast in the shape of a heart!

Ng2lbr4GReOkO57rUTyB0A.text: Sister cafe to nearby Flat White, this trendy joint in Soho knows coffee. Proper coffee. If you're into that strong, unburnt long black (yes, they actually know what that is) at right temperature with proper 'crema' (yes, they know how to do that too), or the flat white with properly heated milk (they even do good soy), then this is the joint for you. More room than Flat White up the road. They have a nice range of counter and hot food, pretty good shakes and primo coffee -Antipodean style. Add all that to the efficient and friendly service and you have a winner. I always stop by for a takeaway coffee if I'm in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom

PBl0a91-9bFqM418tnzCIQ.text: Quite lovely avo smash toastie for breakfast. Really chill place. Maybe a little too chill haha. Staff is great. Minus one star only because for some reason, that day, there a couple of fruit flies that I had to shoo off during my meal. Other than that, lovely!

l3Ljl2cLq-Ww6nGBhIwm2A.text: A beautiful cafeIf u are tired，u could have a cup of latteIf u are sleepy，u could have a cup of AmericanoIf u need a peace space，u could go to MILK

photos.caption: Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom

M9X4jjIo_ix0G7fZ5t16Ig.text: I've stopped by twice and have been disappointed both times. I'll give it one more shot, but for now, I'm not impressed. The first time I stopped by, the wait for drip coffee was over 10 minutes, so I opted for a long black. It was meh. The second time, I came just after 3pm and they stop serving drip at 3pm because they only have two people working. They told us they need at least three people to make drip. Opted for the long black again. Again, it was meh.

N8UtzfkbkUNMUAlWtzROvA.text: Cute spot for a killer cup of coffee. While I'm new to the neighborhood, I instantly felt welcomed and part of this caffeine consuming community. Everything is prepared fresh, from the drinks to the sandwiches all in their perfectly quaint kitchen. Thumbs up!

rns5nEEwIHHhDRfoQAkybA.text: Summary: This review is only for the toast with avocado, scrambled eggs, and BLAT. Went with my +1 for breakfast and we went back later that week because it was go good. The bread in particular is an awesome sourdough. ------DETAILS-----FOOD: Tried the scrambled eggs avocado (comes with toast + lemon slice) + BLAT. The sourdough is amazing - amazing flavor and perfectly crunch but soft texture. The eggs were great though nothing particularly special  and they have a generous portion of avocado. The BLAT is basically the same but bacon, lettuce, avocado, and tomato and it was yummy though I would have preferred either more filling or less bread.SERVICE: Neutral: Nothing to write home about bad or good.ATMOSPHERE: Cute little cafe - not a lot of seating, but haven't had trouble finding it on weekends or weekdays. No laptop policy when there are a lot of people though fyi.

Ic1VCh2uAGmT_VlfA4k0gg.text: I don't really get the hype. It was good...but nothing crazy outstanding. I had a chai latte and avo eggs with bacon. The chai latte was basic and very small. The best thing was the bacon...crispy and delicious. I think there are better options in the SOHO area for a better price.

vOrHfLRm-QD43G_PGQITjQ.text: Average, not really superior to other coffee shops in London or Soho. The latte is 3adi, meaning not special. Lemon and ginger tea is for those with sore throat, like my companion.

photos.caption: Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom

5Hb-2YmUvLZsBr6rCWsMBQ.text: I'll be honest I'm not sure what to make of this discreet coffee place.It's small yet perfectly formed in the heart of soho which is good, but there's no wi fi (it's 2016 folks); it serves quite good coffee, all relatively affordable but has no character for me, just an opinion. Just not feeling the vibe here. I've been here a few times but not sure if call it a place to call on when there are better not far.

3vzt9I3wD2nfR0G8fD-jUA.text: Different coffee places are good for different coffees needs, right?  (just nod along here)So what is Milk Bar good for?Affordable, quality coffee.  I think it's totally reasonably priced, and I like how their flat whites show quality, not quantity: I don't need a massive coffee to get me going in the morning, but I do need a good one.  I also adore their little touches, and have possibly even (embarrassing admission ahead!) Instagrammed their takeaway cups because the hand-drawn sketches are the best.  Feeling a little peckish, too?  Allow me to recommend either their avocado toast or their marmite-n-butter option.  An acquired taste, sure, but...erm...one I have acquired.What is Milk Bar not as good for?Keep in mind it's small...like, real small.  It's not the best place to show up and camp out for hours on end, for a variety of reasons (space, wireless, lighting, as other reviews have mentioned).  Now that I think about it...I'm not sure there is a bathroom?  So, y'know, another strike against camping out there.  Yelp note: one of my best spring mornings = grabbing a flat white, sitting on the bench outside, catching a few AM beams of vitamin D.  Try it! (but leave a little space on the end of the bench for me, too, deal?)

GJsBtUORIMJR-43RWIZ7YA.text: Excellent little independent coffee shop in Soho. Coffee is quick and tasty and the pastries and breakfast is fresh and well prepared. Best if all the staff is super friendly and helpful.

rHcnZOPdd7b3c0QNPQa41w.text: GOOD COFFEE. I don't have much else to say..........I hope this was helpful? It's on par with my other favourite gourmet specialty places, Monmouth and Tapped&Packed.

6OE_j9WZ5oq0XnH8JLZHBg.text: Cute baristas & great coffee - not really sure what more of a reason anyone would need to stop by here.   Seating can be limited as it's only a small space, but they have a a nice selection of pastries to satisfy your sweet tooth while you're wandering the streets of Soho.

RHsfu-vD-BpdAxenzHRzOw.text: Fantastic coffee and food! Soj Milk capuccino is possible and tastes very good.We took the scrambled eggs with avocado en spinach and the granola

1syhdkDMbvdpcT9X7X98lA.text: The rise of independent coffee shops is something I love and I hope London continues the way Sydney went (google Sydney Starbucks). Anyway, this place is great and offers a fantastic coffee. They also offer a tasty breakfast/brunch, however due to the size of the shop it can be quite difficult to find a sit.I will say that Milk bar, unlike a lot of new coffee shops have a GREAT set of staff behind the counter. Happy to serve you. Very central location as well. GO!

_hIwoH2YXoIsBsNBF2q-Qw.text: Having had a strange experience at their sister store, Flat White, we quickly retreated into Milk Bar which was open for business and exuded the smell of coffee throughout the small street where it was located.This is a small, quaint little shop which has a white board for a menu and a huge list of drinks including milk shakes, juices, coffee and teas. There are photographs on the walls making it a sort of gallery since they are displaying normal pictures of every day life in a pleasant way to contribute to the atmosphere of this cozy spot. Their bench chairs were a bit on the tall side and made me feel like I was playing at the kids' table at a doctor's office, but other than that the service was friendly and the coffee came quickly.And good coffee it was. True to their sister name, flat whites are the thing to get here. I, however, tried a latte instead since I was too tired to experiment. Thankfully it worked out quite well and soon we were done with our drinks and well on our way to the day. Onwards!

wo7qXi9pN_XSWayf0FlueQ.text: Growing up in Malaysia, we didn't have dairy cattle in the country. So, all our milk was in powdered, condensed or evaporated form and we didn't grow up with a culture of drinking fresh milk. In fact, I wonder how Malaysians ever got any teeth!So, when I spied Milk Bar, I wondered if anything here would interest me. Well, this is small but trendy cafe serving hot beverages, snacks and some food.However, my eye was drawn to their milkshakes on the menu board. I adore a proper American malt milkshake and that's one of my treats when I'm on holiday in the States. I asked if this was such a milkshake and was told that it wasn't but that it was made with milk and ice cream. That sounded good enough to me and I ordered myself a chocolate milkshake.It was a lovely milkshake though not to the standard of a top 'made in the USA'. I shall return to try their other flavours

photos.caption: Photo of Milk Bar - London, United Kingdom

NmSP1DOBDs_UghIvJczDyA.text: My girlfriend and I had breakfast at Milk Bar last week. My girlfriend is vegan, so it's not always easy to find a good place to eat, but she was really happy with her toast with avocado. I had a great BLAT (sourdough bread) which was fantastic. Also the fresh ginger + lemon and fresh mint tea were great. Would go here again in the future!

WzKjeyA2IYacPe-AJwsvAQ.text: Really out of the way on kind of a desolate road. We definitely wandered a good deal from the tube station before finding this place. Stands out for two reasons though: it's a random, nicely decorated cafe on a street with nothing much else on it and secondly because it's so cramped! All of its three (?) tables are good to seat 1 - 2 people and are stationed right up against the front counter.However, to their credit, it is a clean-cut, cutesy type of place reminiscent of a lot of the hipster-type cafes I saw around other European cities. Not quite the same sort of hipster we do in SF but cute nonetheless.I got the iced chocolate. And soon after, I felt like I should've ordered coffee because they seemed good at coffee but it was what's considered a warm day in London so I wanted something cold. The iced chocolate tasted like chocolate milk blended with some ice. Over in the snacks and sweets, I also saw lots of vegan options.If I stayed in London longer, I feel like I might've come back (hoping there were no more than 3 people already in the cafe) and maybe tried a coffee and then found a table to sit down at with some reading or something.
